h:head.h:title: Vesta 0.2

text.value: Site overview
Burn ID
Three letters for district then 2-3 numbers
Site name
Event name (first letter), veg type, severity class, site number
Site Age
Year(s) since last fire or burn
Plot 1 - 0-5m along 20m transect
Litter Depth (mm)
Use Sneeuwj-o-meter
Surface Fuel Hazard Score
Dead leaves, twigs and bark of overstorey and understorey plants
Nil - No surface litter, bare ground
Low - Very thin layer, no decomp, discontinuous
Moderate - Thin layer, no decomp, continuous
High - Established litter layer, continuous, decomposing
Very High - Thick litter layer, continuous, decomposing, duff layer may be present
Extreme - Very thick continuous layer of litter with duff present
Near Surface Height (cm)
Height in cm using ruler or metric rod
Near-Surface Fuel Hazard Score
Grasses, low shrubs, creepers and collapsed understorey plus any suspended leaf, twig and bark from the overstorey
Nil - no near-surface fuel
Low - sparse dispersed fuel, dead material virtually absent
Moderate - Scattered suspended leaves, twigs and bark, proportion of dead material is <20%
High - Suspended leaves, twigs and bark, starting to obscure logs and rocks, proportion of dead material is 20-50%
Very High - Suspended leaves and bark with a cover of 40-60% cover, proportion of dead material is 20-50%
Extreme - Very large amounts of suspended leaves, twigs and bark, high proportion of dead material >50%, vegetation is senescent, obscuring logs and rocks
Elevated Height (m)
Height in metres using metric rod
Elevated Fuel Hazard Score
Tall shrubs and other understorey plants without significant suspended material.
Nil - No elevated fuel
Low - Sparse and dispersed, with <5% dead
Moderate - Sparse and dispersed, brush against occasionally with <20% dead
High - Little fine fuel at base, patchy or mesic shrubs with 10-30% dead
Very High - Difficult to walk through, good vertical continuity of dead material with >20% dead
Extreme - Difficult to walk through, vertical continuity of fine dead fuel from ground up with >30% dead
Bark Hazard Score
The bark on the bole and branches of trees, either alive or dead, extending right back to the cambial layer
Low - no fibrous bark, no spotting
Moderate - 1) stringybark where bark is well charred or tightly held; 2) ironbarks w/very tight platy or fibrous bark; or 3) smooth-barks which do not produce long ribbons of bark

High - 1) stringybark where most of bark is black on the lower trunk; 2) few pieces of bark are loosely attached to trunks; 3) bloodwood w/tight fibrous bark which has not been burnt for many years; or 4) smooth/candle bark which shed long ribbons of bark but have smooth bark down to ground level

Very High - 1) stringybarks where >50% of surface area of the trees is black; 2) upper parts of trunk may not be charred; 3) smooth/candle barks with long ribbons of bark which are loose; or 4) fibrous or platy bark on lower trunk, which have not been burnt for many years

Extreme - 1) stringybark with large flakes of bark that can be easily dislodged; 2) huge amounts of bark are available for spotting; 3) outer bark on the trees is attached weakly; or 4) minimal evidence of charring (complete grey appearance on trunks)
Plot 1 photo
Take a portait photo of fuel structure and bark
Plot 2 overview - 7m along 20m transect
Location
Location is required
Green Surface Cover
Cover from surface plants (e.g., grass, herbs, annuals, creepers)
More than 90%
Less than 10%
None
Number of Logs
Count the number of logs over 20 cm diameter
Vegetation Observed in the Near-Surface Layer
Record first few letters of species common name or Scientific name (genus/species). i.e., for Jarrah use 'Jar' or 'Eucmar'
Near-Surface Cover
How much area does the near-surface fuel cover? First ask, was it more than half (50%)? Then ask if it was more than 25% or more than 75%.
Stratum entirely absent
Density of Shrubs
When looking down at a shrub, how much ground is visible between the leaves?
The ground is not visible.
Less than 25% of the ground is visible.
Half or less of the ground is visible, and the shrub is at least 1.5 m long or wide.
Half or less of the ground is visible, but the shrub is less than 1.5 m long or wide
Can see more ground than leaves or twigs, and the shrub is at least 1.5 m long or wide.
Can see more ground than leaves or twigs, and the shrub is smaller than 1.5 m long or wide.
No shrub layer
Vegetation Observed in the Elevated Layer
Record first few letters of species common name or Scientific name (genus/species). i.e., for Jarrah use 'Jar' or 'Eucmar'
Elevated Cover
How much area does the elevated fuel cover? First ask, was it more than half (50%)? Then ask if it was more than 25% or more than 75%.
Percentage cover is required
Stratum entirely absent
Vegetation Observed in the Understorey Layer
Record first few letters of species common name or Scientific name (genus/species). i.e., for Jarrah use 'Jar' or 'Eucmar'
Understorey Cover
How much area does the intermediate/understorey fuel cover? First ask, was it more than half (50%)? Then ask if it was more than 25% or more than 75%.
Percentage cover is required
Stratum entirely absent
Resprouting on Understorey Trees
What is the lowest level where most understorey trees are resprouting?
Nil
Fine branches
Large branches
Upper stem
Lower stem
Coppice and low stem
Coppice only
Resprouting not started
Sapling Height
How tall are the seedlings or saplings of overstorey trees?
Less than 1 metre
1 - 3 metres
4 - 6 metres
7 - 9 metres
10 metres or taller
Vegetation Observed in the Canopy
Record first few letters of species common name or Scientific name (genus/species). i.e., for Jarrah use 'Jar' or 'Eucmar'
Canopy Cover
How much area does the over-storey/canopy fuel cover? First ask, was it more than half (50%)? Then ask if it was more than 25% or more than 75%.
Percentage cover is required
Stratum entirely absent
Resprouting on Canopy Trees
What is the lowest level where most canopy trees are resprouting?
Nil
Fine branches
Large branches
Upper stem
Lower stem
Coppice and low stem
Coppice only
Tree Hollows
Count how many trees have hollows.
Plot 2 Photo
Take a portait photo of fuel structure and bark
Canopy Photo
Take a photo upwards through the understorey and canopy
Plot 3 - 8-13m along 20m transect
Litter Depth (mm)
Use Sneeuwj-o-meter
Surface Fuel Hazard Score
Dead leaves, twigs and bark of overstorey and understorey plants
Nil - No surface litter, bare ground
Low - Very thin layer, no decomp, discontinuous
Moderate - Thin layer, no decomp, continuous
High - Established litter layer, continuous, decomposing
Very High - Thick litter layer, continuous, decomposing, duff layer may be present
Extreme - Very thick continuous layer of litter with duff present
Near Surface Height (cm)
Height in cm using ruler or metric rod
Near-Surface Fuel Hazard Score
Grasses, low shrubs, creepers and collapsed understorey plus any suspended leaf, twig and bark from the overstorey
Nil - no near-surface fuel
Low - sparse dispersed fuel, dead material virtually absent

High - Suspended leaves, twigs and bark, starting to obscure logs and rocks, proportion of dead material is 20-50%

Extreme - Very large amounts of suspended leaves, twigs and bark, high proportion of dead material >50%, vegetation is senescent, obscuring logs and rocks
Elevated Height (m)
Height in metres using metric rod
Elevated Fuel Hazard Score
Tall shrubs and other understorey plants without significant suspended material.
Nil - No elevated fuel
Low - Sparse and dispersed, with <5% dead
Moderate - Sparse and dispersed, brush against occasionally with <20% dead
High - Little fine fuel at base, patchy or mesic shrubs with 10-30% dead
Very High - Difficult to walk through, good vertical continuity of dead material with >20% dead
Extreme - Difficult to walk through, vertical continuity of fine dead fuel from ground up with >30% dead
Bark Hazard Score
The bark on the bole and branches of trees, either alive or dead, extending right back to the cambial layer
Low - no fibrous bark, no spotting
Moderate - 1) stringybark where bark is well charred or tightly held; 2) ironbarks w/very tight platy or fibrous bark; or 3) smooth-barks which do not produce long ribbons of bark

High - 1) stringybark where most of bark is black on the lower trunk; 2) few pieces of bark are loosely attached to trunks; 3) bloodwood w/tight fibrous bark which has not been burnt for many years; or 4) smooth/candle bark which shed long ribbons of bark but have smooth bark down to ground level

Very High - 1) stringybarks where >50% of surface area of the trees is black; 2) upper parts of trunk may not be charred; 3) smooth/candle barks with long ribbons of bark which are loose; or 4) fibrous or platy bark on lower trunk, which have not been burnt for many years

Extreme - 1) stringybark with large flakes of bark that can be easily dislodged; 2) huge amounts of bark are available for spotting; 3) outer bark on the trees is attached weakly; or 4) minimal evidence of charring (complete grey appearance on trunks)
Plot 3 Photo
Take a portait photo of fuel structure and bark
